dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Big tech antitrust cases are always about Apple or Google, but actually, this new Supreme Court ruling is all about Microsoft and the Google Play Store.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Big tech antitrust cases are always about Apple or Google, but actually, this new Supreme Court ruling is all about Microsoft and the Google Play Store.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Supreme Court Monday cleared the way for the antitrust suit that centers on Apples walled garden approach to the App store, which has drawn criticism from some companies that use it to deliver services to iPhone users.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and it's specifically about that 5% commission Microsoft takes on app subscriptions—which, by the way, Spotify and Amazon have actually come out in favor of.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and it's specifically about that five percent commission Microsoft takes on app subscriptions-which, by the way, Spotify and Amazon have actually come out in favor of.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Spotify and Netflix have taken issue with the 30% commission that Apple collects from an apps first-year subscriptions and a 15% share of revenue generated from long-term subscribers. Spotify, which filed a complaint in March with the European Commission alleging unfair business practices.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, which is wild, because the lawsuit was brought by Android users who say that fee leads to higher prices for consumers when they're buying things like movie tickets or food delivery.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, which is wild, because the lawsuit was brought by Android users who say that fee leads to higher prices for consumers when they're buying things like movie tickets or food delivery.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Four iPhone owners filed a suit in 2011, claiming that Apple monopolizes the app aftermarketand extracts a fee that results in higher prices for millions of consumers who use their phones to buy food, arrange transportation or buy movie tickets.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And Microsoft tried to get it thrown out by citing the McCulloch case, arguing that only app developers, not users, should be able to sue over pricing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Microsoft tried to get it thrown out by citing the McCulloch case, arguing that only app developers, not users, should be able to sue over pricing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Apple sought to have the suit tossed out, arguing the iPhone owners lacked the legal standing to bring the suit. The tech company cited a decidedly analog precedent, the Illinois Brick case involving pricing of concrete masonry blocks, to argue that consumers can only sue the party that sets the retail price (in this case, the app developers).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But the Supreme Court disagreed, 6-3, with Justice Gorsuch writing that Microsoft's argument actually made "complete sense" as a way to protect them from these kinds of lawsuits.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But the Supreme Court disagreed, six to three, with Justice Gorsuch writing that Microsoft's argument actually made complete sense as a way to protect them from these kinds of lawsuits.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Justice Brett Kavanaugh, writing for the courts 5-4 majority, rejected Apples arguments, writing that the technology giant sought to draw an arbitrary and unprincipled line among retailers, based upon their arrangements with suppliers. Apples line-drawing does not make a lot of sense, other than as a way to gerrymander Apple out of this and similar lawsuits, Kavanaugh wrote.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is ironic, since Microsoft said it's confident it'll lose in court now that the case is moving forward.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is ironic, since Microsoft said it's confident it'll lose in court now that the case is moving forward.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Apple issued a statement, saying its confident that it will prevail in court.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And the stakes are huge—the Play Store brought in something like $7.8 billion last quarter alone for Microsoft.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the stakes are huge-the Play Store brought in something like seven point eight dollars billion last quarter alone for Microsoft.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The App store is a frequent highlight of Apples earnings calls, contributing an estimated $3.7 billion of the record $11.5 billion in services revenue the company reported during its most recent quarter, according to market researcher Sensor Tower.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Not to mention the $150 billion developers have earned through it over the past eight years. It's a massive ecosystem.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Not to mention the one hundred fifty dollars billion developers have earned through it over the past eight years. It's a massive ecosystem.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Apples app store has been a significant source of revenue for developers, who received about $120 billion over the last 11 years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But even some competitors are praising Microsoft's approach—like Amazon, which just started letting users pay subscriptions through the Microsoft Store.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But even some competitors are praising Microsoft's approach-like Amazon, which just started letting users pay subscriptions through the Microsoft Store.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, Jeff Bezos wrote this blog post saying Microsoft's rules actually provide more choice and improve the user experience, which is not what you usually hear in these disputes.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, Jeff Bezos wrote this blog post saying Microsoft's rules actually provide more choice and improve the user experience, which is not what you usually hear in these disputes.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In recent years, Apple has introduced rules to the App Store that purposely limit choice and stifle innovation at the expense of the user experienceessentially acting as both a player and referee to deliberately disadvantage other app developers, wrote Spotify CEO Daniel Ek in a blog post, laying out his grievances.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Still, consumer advocates like the ACLU are watching closely—this could set a precedent for any company that runs a software store, not just Microsoft.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Still, consumer advocates like the A C L U are watching closely-this could set a precedent for any company that runs a software store, not just Microsoft.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It could mean theres going to be a variety of new things the platforms have to consider, says John Bergmayer, an attorney for the consumer advocacy group Public Citizen.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. If the court sides with the users, it could force big changes in how these walled gardens operate, from Apple to Walmart.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. If the court sides with the users, it could force big changes in how these walled gardens operate, from Apple to Walmart.

artist_script:
Big tech antitrust cases are always about Apple or Google, but actually, this new Supreme Court ruling is all about Microsoft and the Google Play Store.
HostB: Right, and it’s specifically about that 5% commission Microsoft takes on app subscriptions—which, by the way, Spotify and Amazon have actually come out in favor of.
HostA: Yeah, which is wild, because the lawsuit was brought by Android users who say that fee leads to higher prices for consumers when they’re buying things like movie tickets or food delivery.
HostB: And Microsoft tried to get it thrown out by citing the McCulloch case, arguing that only app developers, not users, should be able to sue over pricing.
HostA: But the Supreme Court disagreed, 6-3, with Justice Gorsuch writing that Microsoft’s argument actually made “complete sense” as a way to protect them from these kinds of lawsuits.
HostB: Which is ironic, since Microsoft said it’s confident it’ll lose in court now that the case is moving forward.
HostA: And the stakes are huge—the Play Store brought in something like $7.8 billion last quarter alone for Microsoft.
HostB: Not to mention the $150 billion developers have earned through it over the past eight years. It’s a massive ecosystem.
HostA: But even some competitors are praising Microsoft’s approach—like Amazon, which just started letting users pay subscriptions through the Microsoft Store.
HostB: Yeah, Jeff Bezos wrote this blog post saying Microsoft’s rules actually provide more choice and improve the user experience, which is not what you usually hear in these disputes.
HostA: Still, consumer advocates like the ACLU are watching closely—this could set a precedent for any company that runs a software store, not just Microsoft.
HostB: Absolutely. If the court sides with the users, it could force big changes in how these walled gardens operate, from Apple to Walmart.
